sen.j: 葦原中国を平定するに当たって、遣わされたアメノホヒが3年たっても戻って来ないので、次にアメノワカヒコが遣わされた。
sen.e: Amenohohi was the first envoy sent to pacify Ashihara no Nakatsukuni but sent back no report for three years, thus Amenowakahiko was sent as a second envoy.
Amenohohi was the first kami god sent to pacify Ashihara no Nakatsukuni but three years later had still not returned and so Amenowakahiko was sent.

sen.j: しかし、アメノワカヒコは大国主の娘シタテルヒメと結婚し、葦原中国を得ようと企んで8年たっても高天原に戻らなかった。
sen.e: Amenowakahiko, however, took to wife Shitateruhime, the daughter of Okuninushi, and made plans to rule himself over Ashihara no Nakatsukuni and never returned to Takamanohara (plain of high heaven) for eight years.

sen.j: そこでアマテラスとタカミムスビは雉の鳴女を遣して戻ってこない理由を尋ねさせた。
sen.e: Therefore, Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) and Takamimusubi dispatched the pheasant Nakime to inquire of Amenowakahiko's true intentions.

sen.j: すると、その声を聴いたアメノサグメが、不吉な鳥だから射殺すようにとアメノワカヒコに進め、アメノワカヒコは遣された時にタカミムスビから与えられた弓矢（天羽々矢と天鹿児弓）で雉を射抜いた。
sen.e: On hearing the cry of the pheasant Nakime, Amenosagume urged Amenowakahiko to shot the bird, and he used the bow and arrow (Amenohabaya (arrow) and Amakagonoyumi (bow)) entrusted from Takamimusubi to shoot and pierce the pheasant.

On hearing Nakime's cry, Amenowakahiko's vassal, Amenosagume, urged him to kill the bird, at which Amenowakahiko took the bow Amakagonoyumi and the arrow Amenohabaya, which he had received from Takamimusubi on leaving for Ashihara no Nakatsukuni, and shot the pheasant.

sen.j: その矢は高天原のタカミムスビの元まで飛んで行った。
sen.e: The arrow pierced Nakime and continued to climb to heaven where it was found by Takamimusubi in the Plain of High Heaven.

sen.j: タカミムスビは「アメノワカヒコに邪心があるならばこの矢に当たるように」と誓約をして下界に落とすと、矢は寝所で寝ていたアメノワカヒコの胸に刺さり、アメノワカヒコは死んでしまった。
sen.e: Takamimusubi made a vow saying that the arrow would strike Amenowakahiko if he had the false heart and flung the arrow back down at the earth where it struck Amenowakahiko mortally in the breast while he was sleeping in his bed room.

Vowing that the arrow would strike Amenowakahiko if he had a wicked heart, Takamimusubi flung it back down to earth where it struck Amenowakahiko mortally in the breast while he was sleeping in his bedroom.

sen.j: アメノワカヒコの死を嘆くシタテルヒメの泣き声が天まで届くと、アメノワカヒコの父のアマツクニタマは下界に降りて葬儀のため喪屋を建て殯をした。
sen.e: When the wailing voice of Shitateruhime mourning Amenowakahiko's death was carried to the heaven, Amatsukunitama, the father of Amenowakahiko, descended to the earth, built a mourning hut, and wailed in funeral rites.

sen.j: シタテルヒメの兄のアヂスキタカヒコネも弔いに訪れたが、アヂスキタカヒコネがアメノワカヒコに大変よく似ていたため、アメノワカヒコの父と妻が「アメノワカヒコは生きていた」と言って抱きついた。
sen.e: When Ajisukitakahikone, the brother of Shitateruhime, visited to mourn, the father and wife of Amenowakahiko found Ajisukitakahikone as the spitting image of Amenowakahiko and embraced him, saying that Amenowakahiko was alive.

When Ajisukitakahikone, the brother of Shitateruhime, came to pay his respects, his striking resemblance to Amenowakahiko caused the father and wife of Amenowakahiko to embrace him, saying, "Amenowakahiko is alive".

When Ajisukitakahikone, the brother of Shitateruhime, came to pay his respects, his striking resemblance to Amenowakahiko caused the father and wife of Amenowakahiko to embrace him, saying, 'Amenowakahiko is alive'.

sen.j: するとアヂスキタカヒコネは「穢らわしい死人と見間違えるな」と怒り、剣を抜いて喪屋を切り倒し、蹴り飛ばしてしまった。
sen.e: This act enraged Ajisukitakahikone, who yelled "How dare you mistake me for the filthy dead man" and took out his sword to cut down the mourning hut and kick them away.
This act enraged Ajisukitakahikone, who yelled "How dare you mistake me for a filthy dead man" and, drawing his sword, destroyed the mourning hut.
